title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
text: In this notebook, we explore how Python stores and labels information using variables, and how it understands data types like numbers, text, and logic.

title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
text:
ğŸ’¡ What is a variable?
A variable is a name for a value. Think of it like a labelled container.
weight = 1200
Now we can use the word weight instead of typing 1200 again and again.


Code
# Example: storing a value
hippo_weight = 1200
print("Weight of the hippo is", hippo_weight, "kg")


Variables can change:


Code
hippo_weight = 1300
print("Updated weight:", hippo_weight)

title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
section: ğŸ“¦ Common Data Types in Python
text:
ğŸ“¦ Common Data Types in Python



Type
Example
In Excel/SPSS




int
42
Whole numbers


float
3.14
Decimal numbers


str
"Hello"
Text (like â€œFood Groupâ€)


bool
True, False
Logical (TRUE/FALSE)





Code
age = 25          # int
height = 1.78     # float
name = "Gunter"   # str
hungry = True     # bool

print(type(age))
print(type(height))
print(type(name))
print(type(hungry))

title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
text:
ğŸ” Converting Types
Sometimes you need to convert between types:

Excel: =VALUE("123")
Python:



Code
weight_str = "1500"
weight_num = int(weight_str)
print(weight_num + 100)

title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Create a variable called species and assign it your favourite animal as text.
Make a variable legs and assign the number of legs it has.
Try printing both together in a sentence using print().
Optional: convert "2023" (a string) into an integer.

title: ğŸ”¤ Variables and Data Types
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Why do types matter?

You canâ€™t do maths with text
You canâ€™t compare logic with numbers
You might accidentally create â€œ42â€ instead of 42



Type casting (manual conversion)

str(42) â†’ "42"
int("123") â†’ 123
float("3.14") â†’ 3.14

Python is stricter than Excel â€” but thatâ€™s a good thing! It helps avoid silent errors.

title: ğŸš— Python vs R vs Other Tools
text: Data analysis can be done with many tools. This notebook helps you understand where Python fits â€” and why it is widely used in food and nutrition science.

title: ğŸš— Python vs R vs Other Tools
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View








Tool
Strengths
Limitations




Python
General-purpose, readable, automation, machine learning
Slightly more setup


R
Great for statistics, visualisation
Less general-purpose


Excel
Familiar, quick for small tables
No version control, error-prone


SPSS
Menu-driven stats
Less flexible, limited scripts


Prism
Beautiful graphs, quick comparisons
Not programmable


XLStat
Built into Excel, good for sensory
Expensive, closed environment



Python is our tool of choice because: - Itâ€™s open-source and free - It works for small scripts or massive data pipelines - You can write readable code and share it


Code
# Python is readable
data = [2.3, 4.5, 1.2, 5.7]
mean = sum(data) / len(data)
print(f"The average is {mean:.2f}")


Compare with R:
data <- c(2.3, 4.5, 1.2, 5.7)
mean(data)
And Excel:



A




2.3


4.5


1.2


5.7



Use formula: =AVERAGE(A1:A4) â€” but thereâ€™s no clear log of this step.

title: ğŸš— Python vs R vs Other Tools
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand deeper comparisons


Python is often used in pipelines, web apps, dashboards, and modelling
R has ggplot2, dplyr, and built-in stats
Excel is best for one-off reports or small tables â€” not reproducible workflows

title: ğŸš— Python vs R vs Other Tools
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Write a short Python script to calculate the median of [1, 2, 3, 4, 100].
Try making the same plot in Prism and in Python (using seaborn or matplotlib).
Optional: Google â€œPython vs R for epidemiologyâ€ and summarise what you find.

title: ğŸŒ What is a Data Science Environment?
text: Welcome! In this notebook, we explore what a data science environment is â€” and why setting up the right tools can make your work easier, cleaner, and more reproducible.

title: ğŸŒ What is a Data Science Environment?
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View
A data environment is a combination of:

Software: Python, Jupyter, Excel, R
Tools: Notebooks, scripts, version control
Data: CSVs, spreadsheets, databases
Workflows: Reproducible steps, documented processes

Think of it like your lab bench in a research lab. You need the right tools, a clean space, and a way to document what youâ€™ve done.

Why this matters
If you use Excel and manually delete a row or overwrite a number, the change is gone. There is no record of it unless you create backup files (e.g.Â final_final_02.xlsx ğŸ™ƒ).
With Python, your steps are scripted. Anyone (including future-you) can run the same script and get the same output.


Code
# Example: A small data cleaning script
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({
    "Name": ["Hippo", "Giraffe", "Elephant"],
    "Weight_kg": [1500, 900, 3000]
})

# Keep only animals heavier than 1000 kg
df = df[df["Weight_kg"] > 1000]
df


This script tells you what was done â€” filtering animals above 1000 kg â€” and you can re-run it whenever needed.
It also produces the same result each time, unlike an unlogged Excel edit.

title: ğŸŒ What is a Data Science Environment?
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand advanced concepts


IDEs and Notebooks

IDE = Integrated Development Environment (e.g.Â VS Code, PyCharm)
Notebook = An interactive document with code + output + explanation (like this one)



Environments

Use venv or conda to create clean environments
Avoid package conflicts and make your analysis portable



Versioning and Reproducibility

Use Git to track changes to code and notebooks
Document your workflow with Quarto or Markdown

title: ğŸŒ What is a Data Science Environment?
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

In your own words, describe what a data environment is.
Try modifying the Python script above to use 2000 kg as the filter.
Optional: Open a CSV in Excel, change a number, and ask: â€œCan I undo this tomorrow?â€

title: ğŸ§  Finding Help and Documentation
text:
One of the most important skills in data science is knowing how to find help when youâ€™re stuck.
Python (and its ecosystem) has vast documentation and a huge community â€” if you know how to ask.

title: ğŸ§  Finding Help and Documentation
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View

Start with ? in Jupyter
You can get help inside a notebook using a ?:
len?
This shows the docstring â€” the little help box for the function.


Code
# Try running this
len?




The help() function
You can also use Pythonâ€™s built-in help system:
help(len)
Or ask about a package:
import pandas as pd
help(pd.read_csv)


Google it â€” the smart way
Good search terms: - â€œpandas drop NAâ€ - â€œpython list comprehension examplesâ€ - â€œmatplotlib change axis labelsâ€
âŒ Avoid: - â€œPython broken whyâ€ - â€œHelp Python code errorâ€

title: ğŸ§  Finding Help and Documentation
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Official Docs (high quality)

pandas.pydata.org
matplotlib.org
scikit-learn.org
Quarto Docs



Stack Overflow tips

Search for error messages in quotes
Look for posts with âœ… accepted answers
If asking: always include a minimal reproducible example

title: ğŸ§  Finding Help and Documentation
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Use help() to learn about sum() and sorted().
Google â€œpandas groupby plotâ€ and try a small example.
Optional: Try to find the official seaborn documentation and read how to make a violin plot.

title: â˜ï¸ Using Google Colab and Jupyter
text: Jupyter Notebooks are a core tool for interactive data science. In this notebook, we explore two major ways to use them: Google Colab (cloud) and Jupyter (local).

title: â˜ï¸ Using Google Colab and Jupyter
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View
Jupyter Notebooks are documents that mix: - Code cells (you can run) - Markdown cells (text, notes, explanations) - Output (tables, plots, printed messages)
You can run them in two main places:









Platform
What it is
Pros
Cons




Google Colab
Online notebook in your browser
Free, no install needed, good for class
Needs internet


Jupyter
Local app (via Anaconda or pip)
Full control, offline use
Needs install





Code
# A simple code cell
print("Hello from a notebook!")



How to Run a Colab Notebook

Go to your GitHub or shared notebook link
Click â€œOpen in Colabâ€
Run each cell using the â–¶ï¸ icon or Shift + Enter

You can edit, save to your Google Drive, and download as .ipynb or .pdf.


How to Use Jupyter Locally
Install via:
pip install notebook
jupyter notebook
Or install Anaconda to get Jupyter preinstalled.
Youâ€™ll open a browser window with access to your files and can run notebooks just like in Colab.

title: â˜ï¸ Using Google Colab and Jupyter
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Which Should I Use?



Use Case
Tool




Quick work, sharing
Google Colab


Heavy data, offline
Jupyter


Integrating with Git
Jupyter (via VS Code or terminal)





VS Code Integration
You can open and run notebooks directly inside Visual Studio Code with the Jupyter extension â€” handy if you prefer one environment.

title: â˜ï¸ Using Google Colab and Jupyter
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Open this notebook in Google Colab. Run the first cell.
Add a new Markdown cell and type your name using # My name is....
Optional: install Jupyter and open a local notebook file.

title: ğŸ“ Documenting Your Work with Scripts and Logs
text: One of the most common issues in research is poor documentation. Scripts, notebooks, and logs help ensure your work is transparent, repeatable, and understandable.

title: ğŸ“ Documenting Your Work with Scripts and Logs
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View

Why does documentation matter?

So you donâ€™t forget what you did
So someone else can understand your work
So you can re-run your analysis reliably
So you can trust your own results in 6 months!



Example: Undocumented vs Documented Code
âŒ Undocumented:
df = df[df.x > 0]
âœ… Documented:
# Remove negative values from the variable 'x'
df = df[df["x"] > 0]
Just one line of comment makes the purpose clear.


Code
# Example: A basic logging approach
import pandas as pd

print("Loading data...")
df = pd.read_csv("data.csv")

print("Filtering by BMI > 18.5")
df = df[df["BMI"] > 18.5]

print("Saving cleaned file.")
df.to_csv("cleaned.csv", index=False)


This is a very basic form of logging â€” telling yourself or others what happens at each step.

title: ğŸ“ Documenting Your Work with Scripts and Logs
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Real Logging with the logging Module
Python has a built-in logging module for more advanced workflows:
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)

logging.info("Loading data")
This is useful in production scripts and tools.


Good Practices

Use descriptive comments, not obvious ones
Keep a changelog or version history
Use Git to track changes
Write protocol files in Markdown or Quarto to describe:

What you did
What decisions were made
Where the data came from

title: ğŸ“ Documenting Your Work with Scripts and Logs
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Create a short data-cleaning script and add print statements to explain each step.
Try rewriting your print statements using logging.
Optional: Create a markdown file documenting the steps you took and link to your dataset.

title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to this comprehensive teaching resource to help you develop skills in data handling, programming, and statistical analysis using Python.
All materials are structured to be self-guided and modular, supporting both lectures and independent learning. Each section can be explored individually or followed in sequence.





Understand your data environment, tools, platforms, and version control workflows.



Learn how to write Python code, structure your work, and document it effectively.



Import, clean, transform, and manage datasets from simple to complex formats.



Run statistical tests, build models, and explore results through rich visualisations.



Explore Bayesian methods, databases, automation, and dashboards for power users.



Use templates and mini-projects to practice and demonstrate your knowledge.






Source: GitHub Repository
Rendered Site: ggkuhnle.github.io/data-analysis-toolkit-FNS
Run code using Google Colab, Jupyter, or locally on your machine.


ğŸ“Œ Tip: You can dip into any section independently or follow the structure as a progressive course. All notebooks are open-source and available for reuse with attribution.

title: ğŸ“¦ Installing and Managing Python Packages
text:
Python is powerful because of its packages â€” small add-ons that handle everything from statistics to visualisation to web scraping.
This notebook teaches you how to install and manage them.

title: ğŸ“¦ Installing and Managing Python Packages
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View

What is a package?
A package is a reusable collection of Python code â€” like a plugin.
Examples: - pandas â€” for dataframes and analysis - matplotlib â€” for plotting - scipy â€” for statistics


Installing in Google Colab
Colab already includes many packages. To install others:
!pip install seaborn
Try it:


Code
# This will install seaborn in Colab
!pip install seaborn


Once installed, you can import it and use it:
import seaborn as sns


Installing Locally
In your terminal or Anaconda Prompt:
pip install seaborn
Or, if you use Anaconda:
conda install seaborn

title: ğŸ“¦ Installing and Managing Python Packages
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


requirements.txt
You can list the packages your project needs:
pandas==2.0.3
matplotlib>=3.7
Install all with:
pip install -r requirements.txt
Generate it using:
pip freeze > requirements.txt


Virtual environments
To avoid conflicts between projects, create a virtual environment:
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Mac/Linux
venv\Scripts\activate   # On Windows
Then install your packages inside.

title: ğŸ§¾ Notebooks, Scripts, Markdown, or Quarto?
text: Different tools serve different purposes â€” and knowing when to use each helps you write better, clearer, and more reproducible code.

title: ğŸ§¾ Notebooks, Scripts, Markdown, or Quarto?
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View

Notebooks

Best for: Teaching, exploration, walkthroughs
Mix code + narrative + results in one file
Youâ€™re reading a notebook right now!



Scripts (.py)

Best for: Repeating an analysis or cleaning step
Plain Python code, no output inside
Works well for automation and functions



Markdown (.md)

Best for: Notes, documentation, readmes
Simple formatting: headings, bold, links



Quarto (.qmd)

Best for: Reports, websites, academic writing
Combines Markdown + code + rendering engine
Publish to HTML, PDF, Word, slides, dashboards



Code
# Example script (could be saved as clean.py)
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv("mydata.csv")
df = df[df["BMI"] > 18.5]
df.to_csv("cleaned.csv", index=False)


You could run this script every time you get new data â€” itâ€™s repeatable and traceable.

title: ğŸ§¾ Notebooks, Scripts, Markdown, or Quarto?
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Quarto in More Detail

Like R Markdown but supports Python, R, Julia, Bash
Can generate reproducible PDFs (LaTeX), websites, or Word docs
You can write teaching materials with it (like this course)

See quarto.org for examples


Scripts vs Notebooks



Feature
Notebooks
Scripts




Great for demo
âœ…
âŒ


Works in terminal
âŒ
âœ…


Easy to document
âœ…
âš ï¸ (needs comments)


Good for publishing
âœ… (via Quarto)
âœ… (via Quarto)

title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Git and Version Control Basics
text: Version control helps you track changes in your work and collaborate with others. Git is the most popular tool for this â€” and itâ€™s easier than you might think.

title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Git and Version Control Basics
text:
ğŸ’¡ Basic View

What is version control?
Think of it like track changes in Word â€” but for your code, notebooks, and data.
Why it matters: - Revert mistakes easily - See what changed, when, and why - Collaborate without overwriting othersâ€™ work - Protect your analysis history


What is Git?
Git is a tool that tracks versions of files in a project.
With Git, you can: - Save a snapshot of your project (commit) - Back it up online (push to GitHub) - Download updates (pull) - Work with others without overwriting


GitHub: your Git workspace in the cloud

Free (private/public repositories)
Lets you store and browse code, notebooks, and data
You can edit Colab notebooks directly from GitHub!



Code
# You can link to GitHub files in Colab like this:
github_url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/yourusername/yourrepo/main/notebook.ipynb"
print(f"You can open this in Colab: {github_url}")

title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Git and Version Control Basics
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Key Git Commands
git init                # Start versioning a folder
git add .               # Stage all changes
git commit -m "Message" # Save a snapshot
git push                # Upload to GitHub
git pull                # Download latest from GitHub


Version Control Best Practices

Commit small, meaningful changes
Use informative commit messages
Never commit large datasets or passwords!



GUI Options

GitHub Desktop: easy to use, drag-and-drop interface
VS Code Git Integration: powerful + built-in
Command line Git: for full control and scripting

title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Git and Version Control Basics
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Go to github.com and create a free account (if you donâ€™t have one).
Create a new repository for your data coursework.
Clone it using GitHub Desktop or VS Code and add a notebook.
Optional: edit the notebook in Colab via GitHub and commit changes.

title: ğŸ§  What is Code? (And Why Should You Care?)
text:
Welcome! In this notebook, weâ€™ll explore the most fundamental question:
What is code? And what does it do?
If youâ€™ve ever used formulas in Excel, written commands in SPSS, or followed a cooking recipe, youâ€™ve already met the basic idea of coding.

title: ğŸ§  What is Code? (And Why Should You Care?)
section: ğŸ’¡ Code: Giving Instructions to a Computer
text:
ğŸ’¡ Code: Giving Instructions to a Computer
At its heart, code is a series of instructions. Youâ€™re telling the computer what to do, in what order, and sometimes under what conditions.
Think of a recipe:
1. Take two eggs
2. Whisk them
3. Add flour and sugar
4. Bake for 25 minutes
Thatâ€™s a script: a repeatable sequence of steps. Thatâ€™s what we do when we code.

title: ğŸ§  What is Code? (And Why Should You Care?)
text:
ğŸ–¥ï¸ Interpreted vs Compiled Code

Python is an interpreted language: it runs each line one by one.
Languages like C or Java are compiled: theyâ€™re turned into a machine-readable program all at once.

In data science, interpreted languages like Python and R are more popular because theyâ€™re easier to experiment with.


Code
# Let's try a simple script
print("Hello, student!")
print("This is Python running your instructions.")


ğŸ“ In Excel, you might write:
=SUM(A1:A10)
In Python, we write:
sum([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
Same idea: give instructions â†’ get a result.

title: ğŸ§  What is Code? (And Why Should You Care?)
text:
ğŸ§ª Exercises

Write a line of Python that prints your name.
Add another line that prints your favourite food.
Optional: Think of one action you often repeat in Excel or SPSS â€” how might that be expressed as a step-by-step instruction?

title: ğŸ§  What is Code? (And Why Should You Care?)
text:
ğŸ” Advanced View


Click to expand


Code is more than syntax â€” itâ€™s thinking.
Coding trains us to: - Break problems into small steps - Be explicit about what we want - Handle unexpected situations (errors, exceptions)
Over time, youâ€™ll find that even non-coding tasks become more structured â€” this is why programming is such a powerful skill.
